Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 03:37PM TennesseeMichele wrote: Hi everyone, it's good to check in on the Tennessee girls!  My kids have been on spring break and my computer not working so I have a lot to catch up on.  I had tx2 yesterday so am not feeling too tired yet.  Bonny, I am a TN Vol fan so I fit in!  My husband is none too pleased, he's from Ohio, but he shaved his hair when mine came out so he's a good man anyway. Carol, nice to hear your daughter is at MTSU.  We love that school!  My Dad taught there until retirement, my sister-in-law teaches there now, and my husband did his graduate work there.  Our kids also attend the lab school associated with the university.  I'm glad you liked your radiation time at MTMC; I haven't gotten to that stage yet.  And I also like to hear about Adriomycin being dropped from the regimen; makes me feel more secure just receiving TC. Hope everyone's checkups go well.  I'll stop in later. Michele
Posts.Title: Tennessee Thread nelliebelle0361 jenny66

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2008 04:42PM TennesseeMichele wrote: I'm still here!  Is everyone as hot as I am?  It's 94 degrees and almost 7pm - whew! Jan, have you had your surgery yet? Stephanie, how are you?  I was following you on other threads, are you feeling better?  Michele
Posts.Title: Tennessee Thread nelliebelle0361 jenny66

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 07:23PM TennesseeMichele wrote: Hi Debbie,  I've lived in M'boro my entire life, except for college.  You're right, it's getting too big too fast. I'm getting Cytoxan and Taxotere.  Reached my limit of Adriomyacin (spelling?) with my Hodgkin's lymphoma treatment.  Does the fatigue return with every tx? Congrats on finishing tx!   Must be a nice feeling. Michele
Posts.Title: Tennessee Thread nelliebelle0361 jenny66

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2008 03:06PM TennesseeMichele wrote: Hi ShariAnn, Glad you found this site, it's been a great help to me.  Locally here a bs was diagnosed with bc about 18 months ago.  She chose to have lumpectomy, chemo w/o much delay, then mastectomy.  Her feeling was to get the tumor out and then quickly fight the cancer in her body, recover, and then have more surgery. Hugs right back to you! Michele
Posts.Title: Chemo before Masectomy? ShariAnn jdash

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2010 09:06AM TennesseeMichele wrote: My foot neuropathy started about halfway through chemo and lasted for several months after I finished treatment.  It went away so gradually that it took some time to realize it was gone.
Posts.Title: Taxotere Neuropathy - When did you get it? shells43 vnelson

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2008 04:33PM TennesseeMichele wrote: Adrienne, Congratulations on the walk today - we're all proud of you!   Cute new picture, too. Michele
Posts.Title: Here I Go Again? msvirgo828 redheadace1

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2008 01:22PM TennesseeMichele wrote: I'm about 10 weeks out from chemo.  I have almost 1" all over; lots of silver with the brown.  No curls yet.  I decided this week that I was tired of wearing scarves and hats, I was going for it.  I'm getting  lots of "I love it- it looks great!"  and a few "you're so brave!"  I'm not sure what to think when people say that one. My first day out I was dropping items off at the local mission when a man approached me and said, "may I help you sir?"  He was terribly embarassed and I just laughed. I can see eyelashes in my magnifying mirror, and my family is using a magnifying glass to see them too!   At least I know they're on their way.  And the eyebrows are filling in fast.  I hated looking in the mirror to see no eyebrows. Happy weekend! Michele
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 12:07PM TennesseeMichele wrote: Has anybody tried using hair powder to cover the scalp while hair is growing in?  I'm curious about it.  My hair is 1/2" long (I'm about 9 weeks out from chemo) but I don't like how much of the scalp can be seen. Michele
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 16, 2008 11:09PM TennesseeMichele wrote: I can't decide if I want to trim around my ears or not; it's getting curly there, and sometimes the hair sticks out away from my ears.  Kinda silly looking, I think.  But I want it to grow, right?  That's why I can't decide whether or not to trim. Michele
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 10:56PM TennesseeMichele wrote: Hi everyone, Otter, I love your hair!  I think it looks great!  Mine is like Sandy's -  a bit shorter and thinner than yours, only it has more silver (I'm not calling it gray).  I think I'm 15 weeks out; I've lost track. I've gone "topless" for 6 weeks now.  It was too hot to keep covering my head, and I was just ready to move on.  It was awkward at first going out in public, but got easier the more I did it.   Prior to chemo, I had full eyebrows and long, thick eyelashes.  The eyebrows have come back, although not as full, but my poor eyelashes are short, few in number, and growing in different directions.  I don't bother to wear mascara anymore, so at least it saves some time getting ready. I'll post some pictures of the hair growth journey as soon as I can take the time.  I do so enjoy seeing everyone's pictures. Michele
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2008 09:18AM TennesseeMichele wrote: Wow, your sister had lung cancer too, and at such a young age.  Hard to believe.  I had read somewhere that lung cancer was also connected to treatment after Hodgkin's. I had a lumpectomy in Feb, just finished TC chemo, and am starting rads in August.  My hair is  beginning to grow back.  I guess your sister can't have rads again, can she?  Is her pain from the surgery?  If so, you could start a new post with specific questions about that and I'm sure you'll get more answers than I can give since I didn't have a mastectomy. It's wonderful that you're wanting to do so much for her; what a support she has! Michele
Posts.Title: Hodgkin's radiation related jkcroysdale5 jkcroysdale5

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2008 12:42AM TennesseeMichele wrote: Hi jk, I'm so sorry about your sister's diagnosis.  I'm glad you found this site; I usually lurk instead of posting, and I lurk almost daily.  The women here know tons of information about bc and are wonderfully encouraging. I had Hodgkin's lymphoma in 1991 when I was 22, and was diagnosed with bc in Feb at age 39.  For the Hodgkin's I was treated with (chemo) MOPP and ABVD, but did not have radiation.  A few years ago my surgeon contacted me to tell me about the connection between Hl and bc but since I hadn't had radiation I wasn't concerned.  Ha!  Should have taken him more seriously!  From what I read, the women who had MOPP and radiation are the ones now getting bc.   I'm wondering if it's really the MOPP drugs that are the concern. Did your sister have any chemo for her Hodgkin's lymphoma or just radiation?  Hang in there! Michele
Posts.Title: Hodgkin's radiation related jkcroysdale5 jkcroysdale5

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2009 03:00PM TennesseeMichele wrote: When I first asked about my port, my onc told me I would keep it in for a year after my last treatment.  But I just passed my one-year mark of being diagnosed, and he scheduled me to have it removed next week instead.  I have mixed feelings about it coming out, too, although I'm mostly happy to see it go. My surgeon will "de-port" me in his office. Michele

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2009 11:18AM TennesseeMichele wrote: Sparrow,  I finished chemo in July of 08 and wanted to wait until school began to start radiation (the kids school was right down the street from the hospital so it was easy to hit both places near the same time).  My oncs said that it was fine, so I waited about 6 weeks.  Michele
